Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD's finding of adequate state protection in Hungary was reasonable
Application_Facts: Kemenczei claimed persecution due to her Roma ethnicity in Hungary
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of RPD's rejection of refugee claim
Court_Ruling: Application allowed; RPD decision quashed and remanded for reconsideration by a different panel
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution based on ethnic origin (Roma)
Assessment_Factor: Operational effectiveness of state protection against fascist violence
Evidence_Used: Hungary’s legislative efforts to protect minorities
Application_Basis: Claim for refugee protection under the Convention
Evidence_Assessed: Legislative framework in Hungary, lack of analysis on enforcement
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a person in need of protection, refugee status
Governing_Rule: A claimant must demonstrate inadequate state protection to qualify as a Convention refugee or person in need of protection
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD failed to analyze operational effectiveness of protection measures
Outcome: RPD decision set aside, matter remanded for reconsideration
Harm_Assessment: Risk of persecution due to Roma identity in Hungary
Cause_Description: Kemenczei feared persecution in Hungary due to her Roma ethnicity and sought protection in Canada
Evidence_Handling: Insufficient assessment of real-world enforcement of protective laws
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – failure to properly assess state protection
Evidence_Issues: Lack of analysis on actual effectiveness of state protection mechanisms
Evidence_Assessment: Focus on legislative framework without evaluating implementation
Decision_Rationale: The RPD's conclusion was unreasonable due to inadequate analysis of operational protection against fascist violence
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to consider whether laws are effectively enforced in practice
